texts.shortText: There is some confusion about the correct name of this species, which has been referred to by some authors as Anthothoe chilensis. Here we follow WoRMS (World Register of Marine Species) and consider A. chilensis to be a South American species, but see also notes below regarding possible unresolved taxonomy.

Small but common species with a smooth column that can vary from short and squat to elongate and slender. Column smooth and almost always with distinct vertical stripes, colour of stripes ranges from pinks to greens and browns; some specimens can also be very pale and almost white, others very transparent, such that internal organs can be seen through column wall. Tentacles vary widely in number from 130–370. One of most distinctive features is its habit of readily releasing sticky white acontia threads though the body wall whenever disturbed.
Column typically about 20 mm in diameter, but varies widely with individuals from deeper water often being larger.

Global distribution: Namibia, South Africa and Tristan da Cunha Island.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Durban.

Usually found in groups in rock pools and shallow reefs, also under boulders in the intertidal and up to depths of 28 m. Common fouling species on harbour walls, jetties and various floating structures. Photosynthetic symbiotic algae live in the tissues and add to food supply. Preyed upon by the indica nudibranch Anteaeolidiella cacaotica.

Polyphagous opportunistic feeder that also contains photosynthetic algal cells that contribute to its nutrition. Diet in False Bay dominated by isopods, which contributed 62% to numbers of prey in gut. Copepods, polychaetes and spiders each contributed 8% of diet, followed by mites and small gastropods (6% each).

Like most anemones can reproduce both sexually or by fission. In fission the two sides of the foot essentially move apart and the body gradually divides (tears itself) into two genetically identical halves. In sexual reproduction mature gametes are released into the internal cavity (coelenteron) and then spawned through the mouth. The zygotes then develops into planktonic larvae which disperse in the water column, then settle at a new site and develop into new juvenile anemones.

Unlikely to be confused with any other local species due to vertical stripes on smooth column and habit of releasing acontia threads when disturbed. Body shape and size, colour and habitat are, however, extremely variable and it appears likely from recent genetic evidence (Spana et al., 2018) that several distinct but still undescribed species may be present in the region but are included under this one name. These still await formal resolution though.

Branch, G, Griffiths, C, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. Cape Town, Struik Nature. (p. 24)

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. Cape Town, SURG.

Kruger, LM & Griffiths CL (1996). Sources of nutrition in sea anemones from the Western Cape, South Africa. South African Journal of Zoology, 31, 110–119.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Spana C, Haussermann V, Acuna F H, Griffiths CL, Sebb LW & Gomez-Uchida D (2018). Hierarchical biogeographical processes largely explain the genomic divergence patterns in a species complex of sea anemones. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution 127: 217–228.
